title: The 15 Most Affordable Places to Live in America
text:
The 15 Most Affordable Places to Live in America Written by: Laurie Kulikowski 09/21/15 - 9:59 AM EDT 
NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Does living in Ohio appeal to you? If it doesn't, perhaps knowing that the Buckeye State is home to several cities among America's most affordable places to live might change your mind. 
In fact, Midwest cities dominate the top 15 affordable places to live, according to a report out by online real estate listings Web site, Trulia . 
It's not just housing costs that are affordable in many of these middle-class cities. Other fixed expenses, such as commuting costs and utility bills, contribute to the city's affordability. More Headlines 11 Small Colleges That Cost the Least but Reap the Most Earnings 
Trulia sought to get a truly accurate picture of housing affordability in the 100 largest metro areas by measuring what proportion of monthly income is spent on living expenses, like mortgage payments, utility costs and commuting, according to its report out last week. 
Trulia used median incomes from the U.S. Census Bureau's 2013 American Community Survey, adjusted for 2015 dollars. To calculate monthly mortgage payments, it used the median-priced home for sale in the 100 largest areas and based mortgage payments on a 30-year fixed rate loan at 4% interest plus property taxes and insurance. 
To calculate utility costs, Trulia used data from the American Community Survey on median monthly household expenditures for electricity, gas, and water in each of the areas. Commuting costs were calculated by using the median household driving commute time to work for each metro area. Trulia assumed a $7 per hour operating cost (at $3.50 per gallon, 20 miles per gallon average, and 40 miles per hour average speed) plus 25% of the local median hourly wage, it said. 
Ready for the list? Here are the 15 places where it costs relatively little to live. And when you're done be sure to check out which areas are the least affordable to live in. 
15. Columbia, S.C. Monthly Income Spent on Housing, Utilities & Commuting: 33.7% Median Household Income: $51,850 Median Listing Price (as of August 2015): $174,990 
Columbia, S.C., had approximately 132,000 residents as of 2014. Its population rose by 1.5% between April 2010 and July 2014, compared to growth of 4.5% for the entire state of South Carolina, according to the U.S. Census.
